items.body:
We are using skbuild to create a cython extension and a shared libary, which is required by the extension.

The shared library is copied into the the package path just next to the extension and the RPATH is correctly set with cmake. This all works when creating and install binary wheels or via ```python setup.py install```.

However: When creating a source distribution via "python setup.py sdist" and installing the created source distribution via ``pip install source_dist.tar.gz``, the RPATH that is set by ``make install`` is removed by pip.

Is there a way to tell pip the required RPATHS? Using normal setuptools, the RPATH can be set via the ``runtime_library_dirs`` argument of class ``class distutils.core.Extension`` . Can this bis done similarly in skbuild?

items.title: CMake finds wrong F2PY
items.body:
I know [CMake suggests](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/command/find_program.html) to put the unversioned filename in front for the `find_program()` call:

> NAMES
> Specify one or more possible names for the program.
> 
> When using this to specify names with and without a version suffix, we recommend specifying the unversioned name first so that locally-built packages can be found before those provided by distributions.

But in the case of python files this is counterproductive. When you want to build a project for Python 2 where both Python 2 and 3 are installed, this call always finds the default `f2py`:

https://github.com/scikit-build/scikit-build/blob/5b20908709070e6329348aabbb889bacc25ca892/skbuild/resources/cmake/FindF2PY.cmake#L69

At python-control/Slycot#81 this lead to a hard to track down `free(): invalid pointer` error in the python2 packaging for Arch Linux and OpenSUSE, because the wrong f2py was used. As a workaround one can provide the path to the correct executable by adding the variable explicitly during the build call:
`python2 setup.py build -- -DF2PY_EXECUTABLE=/usr/bin/f2py2`

I suggest putting the unversioned filename to the end of the `find_program()` call and additionally making sure that the f2py is from the correct numpy.

```
cmake-3.13.3-cp36-cp36m-win_amd64.whl
[...]
```

Since there are no wheel with a `python tag` including `pypy` or `pypy3`, trying to run `pip install cmake` from a pypy interpreter [fails](https://github.com/scikit-build/scikit-build/pull/418#issuecomment-495091958).

### Toward more generic wheel

Since the CMake wheels (as well as ninja wheels) do not depend on Python C-API, @njsmith  suggested in https://github.com/pypa/manylinux/pull/273#issuecomment-468875632 that we should instead distribute less wheels by using the following convention:

```
cmake-X.Y.Z-py2.py3-none-manylinux2010_x86_64.whl
cmake-X.Y.Z-py2.py3-none-macosx_10_6_x86_64.whl
cmake-X.Y.Z-py2.py3-none-win_amd64.whl
```

This is a great idea and would reduce the number of wheels we have to build. That said, we would have to setup testing for all python version.

Reference:
* https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0427/#file-name-convention
* wheel filename is `{distribution}-{version}(-{build tag})?-{python tag}-{abi tag}-{platform tag}.whl`

items.title: Undesirable behaviour with sdist and symlinks
items.body:
When using `sdist` with setuptools, symlinks are replaced with the concrete files that they reference. I find this useful for keeping a version number consistent across multiple projects in the same repo.

In contrast, when using `sdist` with skbuild, the symlink is not followed, resulting in a (usually) useless symlink being added to the archive. This has proven to be a rather large annoyance in my current attempt at migrating a project over to scikit-build builds.

I have created a minimal example at https://github.com/anibali/issue-skbuild-sdist to exhibit both behaviours.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Clone https://github.com/anibali/issue-skbuild-sdist.
2. Run `SETUPTOOLS=1 python setup.py sdist` to use setuptools' `setup`.
3. Look at the contents of the produced tarball. The VERSION file will be a concrete file.
4. Run `python setup.py sdist` to use skbuild's `setup`.
5. Look at the contents of the produced tarball. The VERSION file will be a useless symlink.

Would using setuptools' sdist in scikit-build's sdist command be a possibility?: https://github.com/scikit-build/scikit-build/blob/master/skbuild/command/sdist.py#L6

items.title: [OSX] skbuild.setup defaults cmake_args without checking kwargs for the arguments.
items.body:
OS: OSX/Darwin (testing on travis).

`setup` checks the command line arguments for `-DCMAKE_OSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET` and for `-DCMAKE_OSX_ARCHITECTURES`, and if they don't exist, it defaults them [here](https://github.com/scikit-build/scikit-build/blob/d8e4db57e0a930db75bd204e47b64ba83a7300bb/skbuild/setuptools_wrap.py#L461-L477). The issue with this is that if the user passed either of those arguments to setup via a kwarg. i.e. `setup(..., cmake_args=[..., "-DCMAKE_OSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET:STRING=10.7"])`, it gets overwritten with the default, even when nothing had been passed to the command line. 
This causes builds to break for no apparent reason (see the reasons for [this PR](https://github.com/skvark/opencv-python/pull/110)). A simple fix is moving the lines where the command line arguments are added to the arguments passed via kwarg from [here](https://github.com/scikit-build/scikit-build/blob/d8e4db57e0a930db75bd204e47b64ba83a7300bb/skbuild/setuptools_wrap.py#L503-L506) to right above the block mentioned above. 
Since `cmake_args` is not referenced between line 477 and line 503, nothing will get more args than it expected, and CLI will still override the args passed via kwarg, but default will only be set if neither the CLI or kwarg `cmake_arg` are set.
If this is approved I will [PR the fix](https://github.com/yonip/scikit-build/commit/2546c18c246857679e469b2a84576e1f802baa65) described above. 
(This is an issue first because the contribution guidelines specify filing bugs before trying to fix them).

items.title: Dies too soon with cmake missing
items.body:
skbuild fails to import if cmake is missing. This means that the following code will not work (untested, so it might not work as is, too):

```python
import subprocess

# Add CMake as a build requirement if cmake is not installed or is too low a version
setup_requires = []
try:
    cmake_version = subprocess.check_output(["cmake", "--version"])
    cmake_version = [int(x) for x in cmake_version.splitlines()[0].split()[-1].split('.')]
    if cmake_version < (3,4):
        setup_requires.append('cmake')
except OSError:
    setup_requires.append('cmake')
```

This forces the addition of `cmake` to the `pyproject.toml`, which could install an older version of cmake (3.10 instead of 3.11), and could affect the user (cmake from python might be installed in the path). If scikit build didn't fail until setup was run (and `setup_requires` was run), then the code at the beginning would be less invasive.

Note: testing code like this is easy with:

```bash
docker run -it ubuntu
apt update && apt install g++ python-pip python-dev git ninja-build
pip install pip==10.0b1
# get a scikit-build project and cd to it
python -m pip install .
```

Due to what I consider a bug in pip 10, you have to use `python -m pip` instead of `pip`.

```bash
  build                     build everything needed to install
  build_py                  "build" pure Python modules (copy to build directory)
  build_ext                 build C/C++ extensions (compile/link to build directory)
  build_clib                build C/C++ libraries used by Python extensions
  build_scripts             "build" scripts (copy and fixup #! line)

  install_lib               install all Python modules (extensions and pure Python)

  install_scripts           install scripts (Python or otherwise)
  install_data              install data files

  bdist_dumb                create a "dumb" built distribution
  bdist_rpm                 create an RPM distribution
  bdist_wininst             create an executable installer for MS Windows

  install_egg_info          Install an .egg-info directory for the package
  bdist_egg                 create an "egg" distribution
  build_sphinx              Build Sphinx documentation
```

```
  build_clib                build C/C++ libraries used by Python extensions
```

items.title: Add "Creating a new release" instructions
items.body:
Here is a draft adapted from:
- https://github.com/girder/girder/blob/master/docs/development.rst
- https://hynek.me/articles/sharing-your-labor-of-love-pypi-quick-and-dirty/

```
Creating a new release
----------------------

Scikit-build releases are uploaded to `PyPI <https://pypi.python.org/pypi/scikit-build>`_
for easy installation via ``pip``. In addition, the python source packages
are stored as releases inside the official
`github repository <https://github.com/scikit-build/scikit-build/releases>`_. The
recommended process for generating a new release is described here.

1.  From the target commit, set the desired version number in ``setup.py``. 
    Create a new commit and note the SHA; this will become the release tag.

2.  Ensure that all tests pass. (AppVeyor, CircleCI and TravisCI should be green)

3.  Run ``python setup.py sdist bdist_wheel``.  This will generate the source
    distribution tarball and wheel in the ``dist`` directory with names like
    ``scikit-build-<version>.tar.gz`` and ``scikit_build-<version>-py2.py3-none-any.whl``.

4.  Create a new virtual environment and install the python package into
    it. This should not be done in the repository
    directory because the wrong ``skbuild`` package would be imported.  ::

        mkdir test && cd test
        virtualenv release
        source release/bin/activate
        pip install ../dist/scikit_build-<version>-py2.py3-none-any.whl

5.  Now you can try to import skbuild.

        python -c "import skbuild"

6. Create a ``~/.pypirc`` 
    consisting of: ::

        [distutils]
        index-servers=
            test

        [test]
        repository = https://testpypi.python.org/pypi
        username = <your user name goes here>
        password = <your password goes here>


Then use ::

        python setup.py register -r test

to register your project with the PyPI test server.

And finally, upload the release to PyPI test server using ``twine``: ::

        pip install twine
        twine upload -r test -s dist/scikit*

7. Test that the release can be installed: ::

        deactivate
        virtualenv install
        source install/bin/activate
        pip install -i https://testpypi.python.org/pypi scikit-build

8. When you are confident everything is working correctly, upload the release
    on PyPI:

First, update ``~/.pypirc``:

        [distutils]
        index-servers=
            pypi
            test

        [pypi]
        repository = https://pypi.python.org/pypi
        username = <your production user name goes here>
        password = <your production password goes here>

        [test]
        repository = https://testpypi.python.org/pypi
        username = <your user name goes here>
        password = <your password goes here>

Second, register the project with the PyPI server: ::

        python setup.py register

And upload the release: ::

        twine upload -s dist/scikit*


9.  Add the tagged version to `readthedocs <https://readthedocs.org/projects/scikit-build/>`_.
```

items.title: Ensure `python setup.py test` calls `nosetests`
items.body:
Integrating `nose` with `setup.py` so that it runs using `python setup.py test` is not straightforward.

The simple approach is to update `setup.py` specifying the following:

```
[...]
test_suite='nose.collector',
[...]
```

Issue is that `nose.collector` doesn't detect nose plugins (e.g coverage). See [here](http://nose.readthedocs.io/en/latest/setuptools_integration.html)

Creating a `NoseTestCommand` in `setup.py` allow to address this. See http://fgimian.github.io/blog/2014/04/27/running-nose-tests-with-plugins-using-the-setuptools-test-command/
